utterances: Or awesome, whichever way you see it.
Or awesome.
But nevertheless, there are other tattoos that can be, well, it's not merely a tattoo, it's a - the phrase ""tramp stamp"" comes to mind.
Well, do explain.
Listen, this comes up in families.
I just got a letter from someone who said that her father was disowning, you know, quote, ""disowning""…
Mm-hmm.
…her 23-year-old sister because the 23-year-old had decided to get a tattoo.
Honestly, this is not something to disown a grown person over.
It absolutely is not.
This falls under the category of picking your battles.
And Neal, you and I came up in the day, in the '60s, when families would have pitched battles over hair length.
Yep.
I mean, do you remember that?
I do.
I remember families torn asunder over hair, and it just seems very silly.
Now tattoos, it's more serious, it's more permanent.
And I do know that 36 percent of Americans between the ages of 18 and 29 have tattoos, so that's a lot of people.
Here's an email from Eric in Scottsdale.
My daughter was over 18, so the issue was moot.
However, my son was not.
I told him I would not stop him from getting the tattoo.
I recommended he have it somewhere that is not readily visible.
He actually listened.
Six years later, when he was job hunting, he thanked me because his employer asked him: any visible tattoos?
When he said no, the employer told him that their customers were conservative and he would not have been able to get the job if he had visible tattoos.
Has been with the company three years now, promoted twice and very happy.
So, much like your young cousin.
Absolutely.
And furthermore, I have interviewed tattoo artists who told me, no reputable, you know, tattoo artist would ink someone under 18.
They're just - you know, piercings are different from tattoos.
A lot of people think that piercings are worse, in a way.
But, you know, piercings are very, very easily reversed.
Undone.
And a tattoo is very, very challenging.
And tattoo artists, reputable ones, say they won't ink anyone under 18 because it's permanent.
Let's see if we can talk with Ryan, Ryan calling us from Fort Wayne.
Yes.
Go ahead.
Yeah.
I was just saying, I have lots of tattoos.
And once my father seen my first one that I got, he wasn't a big fan of it.
He didn't say anything at first.
Eventually, he accosted me about it.
But I went on to get a lot more.

And once I got a tattoo kind of commemorating the family, a family tattoo, he saw that and liked it and ended up getting one himself with his three sons' names in a band around his arm, something very tasteful.
So, like, he ended up coming around.
That sounds like fun.
But Ryan, how old were you when you got the first one?
I was 20 when I got my first one.
I believe around...
So, at that point, it's your body and nobody else's business.
Yeah.
But I guess I grew up under the - one of the households where - I still tried to hide it for the longest time.
And you know, honestly, even when I still do go around in family events I don't wear shorts, usually, just to hide some tattoos.
But it's not as frowned as it used to be, I suppose.
It has.
It has.

But I would say, and I spoke with my young cousin about this way back in the day, I urged him to go pay a visit with our uncle who is in his 80s and got his own tattoo when he was in the Merchant Marine back in the '40s, of a ship.
And let me just tell you, on old skin, that ship has sailed.
(Soundbite of laughter)
You know, older skin, you have to imagine the effect of aging, sagging skin on your tattoo.
You have to try and imagine that.
And I know young people, you can never imagine it.
But it's something, in about 25 years, we're going to be really dealing with.
Ryan, good luck.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Bye-bye.
Let's go next to Sasha, Sasha with us from San Francisco.
Hello.
I actually am a tattoo artist.
And I had two comments.
One is I actually had parents either call or come in with their teenager and ask if we can tattoo them.
And of course, we can't in California, under 18.
And it's so interesting because I think parents are trying to be the cool parent that says okay, but inevitably they're all relieved.
You know - all relieved.
(Soundbite of laughter)
They're all relieved when I say I can't tattoo their teenager.
And so, that's - just wanted to throw that out there.
But some of them really do actually even say, well, if you want to do this, we'll come in with you.
But we can't do it…
Mm-hmm.
…In California.
In California.
The other point you wanted to make?
The other one, I just wanted to - the comment that Amy just said about tattoos looking bad in the 80s.
Just a technical issue is that a lot of the tattoos that were done 60 years ago were done too small.
And so, if they're done well, they won't look as bad.
So I just wanted to just say on a technical issue.
I'm sure the tattoo will look fine.
My skin, I'm not so sure about that.
Yeah.
Skin I can't help you with.
But that's - I just wanted to say from a tattoo artist, I've seen parents come in.
So, thanks.
Thanks very much.
And Amy, we're in a new world where, yes, you and I were of the generation where parents were, like Sasha was talking about, relieved when it turns out this could not happen.
But again, this is a new day.
This is a new day.
And I have a sister who has a tattoo, got it in her 40s.
Many adults I know have tattoos or are getting them.
And it really should be considered a matter of personal choice.

And I think that, you know, this is the - this is one of the great lessons in terms of parenting is that we try to raise our children so that by the time they're in their teens and later teens, we're turning their lives over to them.
And so, you say, look, here's the story with tattoos.
When you're 18, if you choose this, that's your choice.
The consequences are as follows.
But should you disown?
I mean, it's one thing if your child chooses to get a tattoo that's so visible and if it's a symbol of hate or something that - or if it's against your religion, that's another matter.
But in terms of just a personal choice, I think it should not be a deal breaker.
Let's go next to Dave.
Dave with us from Corvallis in Oregon.
Hi, Neal.

I just wanted to - you know, it's interesting about the parental thing, is that because when my children were very little, I was very adamant about opening up a lot of rock and roll kind of music to them.
And my son, who's now a musician - he's 19 and I'm 45 - he's a drummer and a guitar player.
And he knew all along that I was very opposed to tattoos and that kind of thing.
And - but now he's got a Jimi Hendrix tattoo - and let me also say that his mother is an art history major.
So he's got this beautiful Jimi Hendrix tattoo on his shoulder and he's like, hey, dad, you know what, this is the music you brought me up with, and mom is the, this art stuff.
So, there's a part of me that is really grieving about what he's doing with these tattoos because they're permanent and they're long-lasting.
Not only that, we're Jewish.
And so, I just, you know, I guess there's always this thing, you can't be buried in the cemetery with tattoos, you know?
So, anyway, but there's this ongoing thing with my kids, and they even teases me about getting a Beatles tattoo on my leg because I don't like the Beatles.
(Soundbite of laughter)
That's just to get in your head, Dave.
The Jewish issue - you mentioned religion just a moment ago, Amy - that's very real for some people.
It is.
And in fact, my cousin, who I am mentioning, is also Jewish.
And he said that when he went to Israel, the border, you know, guards, he was dealing with could not believe that he was Jewish because he did have body art.
And he was - he said he was asked to recite Torah portions that he hadn't remembered since his bar mitzvah.
So...
Just to prove it.
